title: Joe Hamilton (American football)
text:
Joseph Fitzgerald Hamilton (born March 13, 1977) is a former American college and professional <a href="American%20football">football</a> player who was a <a href="quarterback">quarterback</a> in three different professional leagues. He played <a href="college%20football">college football</a> for the <a href="Georgia%20Institute%20of%20Technology">Georgia Institute of Technology</a>, earned <a href="All-American">All-American</a> recognition and won several national awards. After his playing career ended, Hamilton became an administrator and coach. He has served as the running backs coach for <a href="Georgia%20State%20University">Georgia State University</a> and currently works in the recruiting department for his alma mater, Georgia Tech.
College career.
Hamilton accepted an <a href="athletic%20scholarship">athletic scholarship</a> to attend Georgia Tech, where he played for the <a href="Georgia%20Tech%20Yellow%20Jackets%20football">Georgia Tech Yellow Jackets football</a> team from 1996 to 1999. He set <a href="Atlantic%20Coast%20Conference">Atlantic Coast Conference</a> (ACC) career records for total offense (10,640 yards), touchdown passes (65) and total touchdowns (83). As a senior in 1999, he was recognized as a consensus first-team All-American, won the <a href="Davey%20O%27Brien%20Award">Davey O'Brien Award</a>, and was a finalist for the <a href="Heisman%20Trophy">Heisman Trophy</a>, finishing as the runner-up in the Heisman voting behind <a href="Wisconsin%20Badgers%20football">Wisconsin</a> <a href="running%20back">running back</a> <a href="Ron%20Dayne">Ron Dayne</a>. In 2002, he was named as one of the fifty members of the ACC 50th Anniversary Football Team. Hamilton was elected to the <a href="College%20Football%20Hall%20of%20Fame">College Football Hall of Fame</a> in 2014.
Professional career.
Due to his lack of prototypical height for an <a href="National%20Football%20League">NFL</a> quarterback (standing just 5'10"/1.78 m), he fell to the 7th round of the <a href="2000%20NFL%20Draft">2000 NFL Draft</a> before being drafted by the <a href="Tampa%20Bay%20Buccaneers">Tampa Bay Buccaneers</a>. In three years with the Buccaneers he only played four downs in a single regular-season game. In 2002, the Buccaneers allocated Hamilton to <a href="NFL%20Europe">NFL Europe</a>, where he led the <a href="Frankfurt%20Galaxy">Frankfurt Galaxy</a> to 5-2 record in 2002 before suffering a severe knee injury (<a href="Anterior%20cruciate%20ligament%20injury">torn ACL</a>). He spent the entire <a href="2002%20NFL%20season">2002 NFL season</a> on <a href="injured%20reserve">injured reserve</a> and was released by the Buccaneers at the end of the season. He received a <a href="Super%20Bowl%20ring">Super Bowl ring</a> following the Buccaneers' victory in <a href="Super%20Bowl%20XXXVII">Super Bowl XXXVII</a>.
He signed with the Arena Football League's Orlando Predators in 2004 and guided the team to a 9-5 record and the playoffs, despite suffering another knee injury and missing two and a half games.
He was then signed by the <a href="Indianapolis%20Colts">Indianapolis Colts</a> in 2004, reuniting with former Buccaneers coach <a href="Tony%20Dungy">Tony Dungy</a>, but only saw limited action in one game before being released during the season.
He returned to the <a href="Orlando%20Predators">Orlando Predators</a> where he was the <a href="Starting%20lineup">starting</a> quarterback through the <a href="2006%20Arena%20Football%20League%20season">2006 season</a>. He has a 32-15 record as the Predators' starter and led them to <a href="ArenaBowl%20XX">ArenaBowl XX</a> in 2006, losing 69-61 to the <a href="Chicago%20Rush">Chicago Rush</a>. With a win, Hamilton would have become the first player in history to own both a Super Bowl and ArenaBowl ring. In the 2006 off-season, he was released by the Orlando Predators.
Post-playing career.
He returned to school, and received his degree in History, Technology, and Society in August 2007. "
In 2008, following an arrest for a hit and run, DUI, open container and marijuana possession, Joe Hamilton resigned as a Georgia Tech assistant coach—less than two weeks after he was hired.
In 2010, he resurrected his coaching career when he became a recruiting intern at Georgia State, which had launched its <a href="Georgia%20State%20Panthers%20football">Georgia State Panthers football</a> team that year. In June 2011, he joined the Panthers' full-time staff as running backs coach. On May 7, 2013, exactly 5 years after submitting his resignation, Hamilton was re-hired by Georgia Tech to provide assistance with recruiting for the Yellow Jackets football team.
Currently, Hamilton is the co-host of The Locker Room, a morning sports radio program on <a href="WCNN">WCNN</a> in Atlanta.
